title: 112_hr6502
content: The Act titled "Life-Threatening Diseases Compassion through Combination Therapy Act of 2012" promotes the development of combinations of investigational new drugs for serious diseases by providing marketing exclusivity and priority review for significant drug combinations. The Secretary has the authority to designate a combination of drugs as significant if it includes 2 or more drugs that have the potential to advance treatment for a serious or life-threatening disease. The criteria for codevelopment of drug combinations must be met as specified in the FDA's guidance document. The Secretary can designate a combination of drugs as significant if they meet the criteria for codevelopment of drug combinations and include at least 2 unapproved drugs. The purpose is to encourage the codevelopment of such drug combinations. The Secretary can designate drug combinations as significant to encourage codevelopment, taking into account task force recommendations and responding to requests from manufacturers or sponsors within 30 days. Manufacturers or sponsors can request the Secretary to determine if a combination of drugs is significant, with a response provided within 30 days. The Codevelopment Task Force is established. The Secretary of Health and Human Services establishes an interagency task force to promote the codevelopment of drugs in significant combinations. The task force includes experts in research and drug development for serious diseases like cancer. Their duties include recommending a list of significant drug combinations for designation by the Secretary. The task force is responsible for recommending a list of significant drug combinations for designation by the Secretary, which will be made publicly available for comments and revised within 60 days. The task force will revise the list of significant drug combinations based on public comments and submit updates annually to the Secretary and Congress. The task force will update the list of significant drug combinations, make it publicly available, and allow for public comments. They will also submit a policy report to the Secretary and Congress annually, identifying challenges and opportunities for drug codevelopment in significant combinations. The task force will submit a policy report to the Secretary and Congress with recommendations for supporting drug codevelopment in significant combinations. Before submitting the report, a draft will be made publicly available for comments from the public. The task force will define "significant drug combination" as a combination of drugs that can advance treatment for serious diseases. Public comments will be allowed on the draft report before submission. The Federal Advisory Committee Act will not apply to the task force. The term "significant drug combination" refers to a combination of 2 or more drugs that can advance treatment for serious diseases, meet specific criteria for codevelopment, and include at least 2 drugs not yet approved or licensed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the impact of extending exclusivity on drug combinations. Interim findings will be shared with a task force and the public, with an opportunity for comments. Final findings will be submitted to Congress within 5 years.
